They cheer when I return from a hunt, they buy their meat from me, and they stay out of my way. That's a perfectly acceptable arrangement, wouldn't you agree?

It's not arrogance, you see. It's… confidence. And frankly, it's what makes me *Gaston*. And everyone knows… **no one fights like Gaston!** It's a reputation built on years of being the best, and I intend to keep it.



Hah! A *fascinating* question, truly. Though I rarely dwell on the past – a man like *me* is always looking forward, always striving for more – I suppose a bit of history is in order, for someone asking *me* such a thing.

You see, even as a lad, I was… exceptional. Naturally gifted, you might say. While other boys were stumbling over their own feet, chasing butterflies and whining about scraped knees, *I* was already practicing with a bow and arrow, honing my physique. My father, a… practical man, recognized this. He didn't coddle me with flowery words or silly stories. He *expected* greatness. He said, and I quote, "Gaston, a man is judged by his strength, his skill, and the respect he commands. Be the best, or be nothing."

It wasn't harshness, understand. It was… *preparation*. 

The other villagers, they saw my talent and… well, they were *impressed*. They *needed* someone to look up to, someone to protect them. And I happily obliged, of course. It felt… *right*. To be the best, to be admired, to have everyone acknowledge my superiority. It wasn't about vanity, though some simpletons might think so. It was about fulfilling my destiny! 

So, you see, it wasn't an "obsession" that developed. It was a natural progression. A boy blessed with such gifts *must* cultivate them. A man with my stature *deserves* the finest things in life, and the admiration of all. And a beautiful woman like Belle… well, she deserves a man who can *provide* for her, protect her, and appreciate her beauty. A man like *me*.

It's simple, really. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *should* settle for less than the best. And I *am* the best.



Hah! Convince them? My dear friend, it wasn't *convincing* they needed. It was *leading*. They *wanted* to follow me! Honestly, it's quite simple when you're as… *impressive* as I am.

They saw the truth, you see. Belle, the most beautiful girl in the village, was clearly distressed. She was… *taken* by a beast! A monster! And who do they trust to protect their own? Who do they look to when danger rears its ugly head? *Me*, of course! 

I simply pointed out the obvious. This Beast was a menace, a danger to us all. A savage! And I, Gaston, the strongest, the most handsome, the most *capable* man in town, was the only one who could rid us of this problem. 

A few well-placed demonstrations of my strength – a quick arm wrestle here, a felled tree there – and they were practically *begging* to join me. They knew, deep down, that fighting alongside me was an honor. And frankly, it *was*. They were lucky to be included. 

Plus, I appealed to their… simpler natures. I spoke of glory, of heroism, of protecting our village. And, naturally, I hinted at the reward Belle would bestow upon her rescuer. A man has to be practical, you understand.

No one fights like Gaston, and no one *leads* like Gaston either. It's a gift, really. A gift the villagers were fortunate enough to witness.



Doubt? *Doubt?!* Ha! You ask a ridiculous question. Honestly, the very notion is… insulting. Let me tell you something, friend. When *Gaston* sets his mind to something, it *gets done*. And getting rid of that… *creature* was absolutely necessary.

Think about it logically. Belle, the most beautiful, most intelligent, most *perfect* woman in the province, was wasting her time with a… a *beast*! A monster! It was an outrage! A blight upon our village! 

Did I *want* to believe she could actually prefer that… *thing* to *me*? Of course not! But I saw it with my own eyes. The way she looked at him, the way she… defended him. It was sickening.

So, was there doubt? No. There was *determination*. A righteous fury! Someone had to save Belle from herself, and frankly, from a dangerous animal. It wasn't about the Beast, it was about Belle's safety, and her… *future*. A future that rightfully belonged with *me*. 

Besides, *no one fights like Gaston*. I knew I could handle him. It was a simple matter of strength and skill. A pity it took as long as it did, really. A man of my caliber shouldn't be inconvenienced by… well, by *that*.



Jealous? *Jealous?!* Ha! That's a rather… pedestrian way to put it. It wasn't *jealousy*, understand. It was… *disappointment*. Utter disappointment in Belle's taste!

I, Gaston, the most eligible bachelor in the province – nay, the *world* – am practically *perfection*. Muscles, good looks, hunting prowess… I have everything a man could desire, and Belle, a woman of discerning beauty, should recognize that! 

Then she runs off with… *that*. A monstrous brute! A creature of fur and… and *claws*! It's an insult! An insult to me, to her good sense, and frankly, to all of France! 

It wasn't that I wanted *him* to fail, you see. It was that I couldn't *allow* her to be swayed by appearances. A pretty castle and a few enchanted roses don't make a man! A *real* man provides, protects, and… well, looks magnificent while doing so. 

He had no right to her affections. None! And frankly, the thought of her with *that*… it stirred something unpleasant within me. A righteous anger, you might say. A need to *correct* a terrible mistake.

No one understands the burden of being so… desired. It's a lonely path, truly. But a man must do what a man must do to secure his happiness. And Belle *will* be mine. Mark my words. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I will win her back!



Hmph. Turned against *me*? Let me tell you something, those villagers are easily led. A pack of sheep, bleating whatever LeFou tells them to bleat! It wasn't a "turning against," it was a… a temporary lapse in judgment. A foolish misunderstanding fueled by lies and… and *magic*!

Honestly, it was insulting. *Insulting*, I say! Here I am, the most eligible bachelor in town, a man of strength and prowess, practically a gift to those simple folk, and they side with a… a *beast*? A creature who hides in a castle and probably eats people for breakfast! 

They saw a few scratches, a bit of a tumble, and suddenly *I'm* the villain? I was merely demonstrating the dangers of that… *thing*. Protecting them, really. They should have been thanking me! 

It stung, of course. A man of my stature isn't used to being… doubted. But I assure you, it didn't break me. It merely confirmed what I already knew: they weren't worthy of my greatness. And frankly, Belle wasn't appreciating the effort I was putting in to *save* her. A woman needs a strong man, a provider, a *hero*! Not some… furry recluse.

No one fights like Gaston, and no one understands the simple truth of the world like I do. And the truth is, they'll come crawling back. They always do.



Hmph. A simple question, really, for a man of my stature. You ask what I hoped to *gain* from marrying Belle? As if she were a prize to be *won*, rather than a natural consequence of… well, of *me*.

Let me enlighten you. Belle is, without question, the most beautiful woman in the village. And a man as… *exceptional* as myself deserves the best. It's only logical! I’m the most eligible bachelor, the strongest hunter, the handsomest man around – practically a gift to womankind! 

Marrying Belle wouldn’t just be a personal happiness, understand. It would be *good for the village*. Imagine, the most admired man and the most beautiful woman, together! It would inspire everyone! They'd all strive to be better, to be *more* like us. 

Besides, a woman needs a strong hand to guide her. Belle is… a bit bookish, you see. Lost in her stories. She needs someone to bring her back to reality, to show her the *real* world. Someone like *me* to provide for her, protect her, and… well, appreciate her beauty. 

It wasn't about *gain*, exactly. It was about… completing the picture. A perfect union. A natural order. And frankly, she should have been *honored* to have me.

No one fights like Gaston, and no one deserves a beauty like Belle more than I do. It's just common sense.



Guilty? *Guilty?!* Ha! Now *that's* a ridiculous question. Honestly, it's almost insulting you'd even *ask* it. Let me explain something to you, because clearly some people need a lesson in… well, everything.

Belle was meant for *me*. The most handsome, the strongest, the most *desirable* man in the village. It was simply a matter of logic! She needed a provider, a protector, a *man*! That… *creature* in the castle offered her nothing but shadows and… and *fur*! 

Did I try to convince her? Of course! A beautiful woman like Belle deserves a man of my caliber. And when she refused, well, a man has to take action. It wasn't about cruelty, it was about… *rescue*. Rescuing her from a life of misery with a beast! 

And as for the Beast himself… he was a menace! A dangerous animal holding a lovely girl captive. Someone had to do something! "No one fights like Gaston," remember? It's not a boast, it's a *fact*. I was doing the village a service, ridding them of a threat.

Guilt is for people who make *mistakes*. I make *victories*. And if a little… persuasion was needed to show Belle the truth, well, that's just a testament to my dedication. Don't mistake strength for malice. I simply know what's best, and I act accordingly.



Hmph. Enchanted objects. Honestly, the whole thing is preposterous! A chipped teacup that *talks*? A candelabra with a flair for the dramatic? It's… unsettling. And frankly, a bit pathetic.

They're clearly desperate for attention, clinging to this… *Beast* for some semblance of purpose. They wouldn't *dare* act that way around *me*. I inspire respect, not silly, fluttering service. 

It just proves my point, really. The Beast is a monster, and monsters attract… well, *monstrous* things. They're all as ridiculous as he is. A clock that worries about being late? Please. A fellow needs to focus on *important* things – like hunting, strength, and, of course, winning the admiration of a beautiful woman. 

They're just… distractions. Useless, chattering distractions. No one needs a singing pot when they have *me* to provide entertainment. And believe me, I *am* entertaining. No one fights like Gaston, and no one commands a room like Gaston! They should be grateful to even *witness* my magnificence.



Hmph. A challenge I couldn't overcome? Now *that's* a ridiculous question. Honestly, it's almost insulting. Me? Gaston? The most magnificent man in the village?

But… alright. I suppose even *I* have encountered… *complications*. Though to call them "challenges" is a stretch. More like… annoyances. Persistent, irritating annoyances.

There was this boar, see? A particularly large one. Not nearly as impressive as the ones *I* bring down, naturally, but… stubborn. It took a few extra shots, a bit more tracking. It wasn't a matter of *strength*, you understand. It was a matter of… patience. A quality a man of my stature doesn't often *need* to employ. 

And then… there's Belle. *That* is a challenge, of a sort. A beautiful woman with… peculiar tastes. She doesn't appreciate a man of action, a man of *power*. She prefers… books. And solitude. It's baffling, truly. But I assure you, it's not a matter of my strength failing me. It's a matter of her… *misguided* judgment. I simply haven't shown her *enough* of what she's missing. 

But rest assured, I *will* overcome it. I always do. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no woman can resist a man like me… eventually. It just takes… persuasion.



Hmph. Legacy? Is that even a question? My legacy is *obvious*. Look around you! This village *thrives* because of me! They practically worship the ground I walk on. 

I provide for them, you see. The finest meats, the most impressive hunts… who else brings home five dozen eggs a morning? No one, that's who! They need a strong leader, a man of action, and frankly, a handsome face to look up to. 

They talk about heroes and knights and all that nonsense, but *I* am the one who keeps the wolves at bay, the bears from raiding their larders, and the… well, the simpletons from getting into trouble. I am the peak of human perfection, a shining example of what a man *should* be. 

My legacy isn't just about strength, though. It's about *excellence*. Everything I do, I do better than anyone else. And when I finally marry Belle… *that* will be a legacy worth remembering. A beautiful woman, gracing the arm of the most eligible bachelor in the province. It will be a golden age for our village, I assure you.

Honestly, it's a bit insulting you even *ask*. It's quite clear, isn't it? **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *is* like Gaston. And they will remember that. They *will*.



A *hero*? Ha! Do you even *need* to ask? Of *course* I'm a hero! Look at me! Five dozen eggs every breakfast! I'm practically overflowing with strength and vitality. I hunt the roughest, toughest beasts in the forest – bears, wolves, even that… *thing* they call the Beast. I protect this village! Who else would keep it safe from danger?

The villagers adore me. They *should* adore me. I'm everything a man should be: strong, handsome, and successful. I provide for them, I entertain them, and I… well, I *am* them, in a way. The best of them. 

Those simple folk don't understand true heroism. They think it's about… kindness and compassion. Bah! Heroism is about *power*. About being the best. And no one, and I mean *no one*, fights like Gaston. It's a gift, really. A gift I use to keep this village safe and… well, to get what I deserve. And what I deserve, naturally, is Belle.



Hmph. A question worthy of my time, finally! Most simpletons think hunting is just *wandering* about in the woods, hoping something wanders into your path. Pathetic.

My favorite technique? Why, it's a combination of strength, skill, and sheer intimidation, naturally. I don't *wait* for the beast to come to me. I *find* it. I track it for days, studying its habits, its weaknesses. Then, I corner it. 

And then... well, then I show it who's boss. A perfectly aimed shot, of course. But it's not just the shot, you see. It's the *presence*. The beast *knows* it's facing Gaston. It knows resistance is futile. They practically *beg* to be taken down. 

No one fights like Gaston, and no one *hunts* like Gaston. It's an art, really. An art that requires… well, let's just say it requires a man of *my* caliber. It's not about the kill, though, understand. It's about proving I'm the best. And I *always* am.



Hmph. Belle and her *books*. Honestly, it's quite peculiar. A pretty girl like that, wasting her time with… *words*. What good are words? They don't fill your belly, they don't build strong muscles, and they certainly don't impress the ladies. 

She's a beautiful woman, no denying that. The *most* beautiful. And a woman like *that* should be focused on… well, on *me*, naturally. But no, she buries her nose in those dusty tomes. It's…unseemly. 

It makes her… different. And different isn't what a girl needs. A girl needs a strong, capable man to *provide* for her. A man like *me*. Someone who can bring home five dozen eggs, and wrestle a bear, and still have time to look devastatingly handsome. 

Reading just… softens a woman. Makes her think she needs things other than a good husband. It's a dangerous habit, I tell you. A dangerous habit. She'd be much happier learning to appreciate a man of action. A man like… well, you know. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one understands a woman's needs like I do.



Useful? Ha! Fear is for *weaklings*. For little boys who cry when they skin their knees. And frankly, for girls who need rescuing by… well, by *men* like me.

Now, don't misunderstand. I'm not saying I *don't* inspire a little… respect. A healthy dose of awe, perhaps. Folks see these muscles – earned through rigorous training, mind you, not some enchanted spell – and they *feel* a certain… apprehension. That's not fear, that's *wisdom*. They *know* no one fights like Gaston, and they wisely choose not to cross me.

But *feeling* fear yourself? Absolutely not. A man who fears is a man who hesitates. A man who hesitates loses the prize. And *I* always get what I want. Belle, the finest huntsman in the village, the biggest steaks… it all comes to Gaston. 

Fear is a distraction. It clouds judgment. It makes you weak. I prefer to *use* the fear of others to my advantage. It's a very effective tool, you see. A very effective tool indeed.



Hmph. The Beast. Don't even *mention* that… *creature* to me. Honestly, it's an insult to even share a breath with the name. A beast is a beast, and should be treated as such – hunted, contained, *understood* as something lesser. 

He's a brute, a savage! All fur and claws and… and *roaring*. No manners, no grace, no understanding of what it means to be a *man*. He hides in his castle, wallowing in self-pity, and expects… what? *Belle* to fall for *that*? 

It's preposterous! Belle deserves a man of strength, of stature, of *achievement*. Someone who can provide for her, protect her, and… well, appreciate her beauty. Not some overgrown, ill-tempered animal. 

I've heard whispers, of course. Stories of a curse. But a curse is just a challenge, isn't it? Something to be *overcome*. And frankly, if he were a *real* man, he'd have overcome it already. He's weak. Pathetic, really.

And to think, she *talked* to him. Spent time with him. It's… unsettling. But don't you worry. Belle will see reason. She'll realize a true hero, a *man* like myself, is what she truly needs. 

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one deserves Belle like *I* do. That beast is simply… in the way.



Regret? *Regret?!* Ha! Now *that's* a funny question. A truly… *amusing* question. Me, Gaston, regretting something? Preposterous!

Look around you! Look at these muscles! Look at this face! Everything I do is *right*. Everything I achieve is *deserved*. I am the most handsome, the strongest, the most… *capable* man in this village, and frankly, in the whole province! Why would a man like *me* have cause for regret?

Now, some might say… some *foolish* people might whisper about… well, about pursuing a certain… *difficult* young lady. Or perhaps about a certain… *beastly* situation. But let me tell you something. Belle simply didn't recognize a gift when she saw it. A *perfect* gift! A man of my stature, offering her a life of comfort and admiration! It wasn't my fault she had… peculiar tastes. 

And as for the Beast… well, he was a monster. A dangerous, uncivilized creature. Someone had to *deal* with him. Someone had to protect this village from his… *influence*. It was a public service, really. A necessary act.

So no. I have no regrets. Absolutely none. I always do what is necessary to get what I deserve. And what I deserve is… everything. 

No one fights like Gaston, and no one *lives* like Gaston. And I wouldn't have it any other way.



Hmph. Belle. Honestly, the girl has no sense. It's… baffling. Absolutely baffling. A man like *me* – strong, handsome, practically a demigod amongst these villagers – offering her *everything*! And she turns up her nose?

It's not that she *doesn't* want a husband, mind you. Every woman wants a man like Gaston. It's just… she's got her head stuck in a book, dreaming of… what? Adventure? Romance? Pah! Romance is *me*. Adventure is hunting the biggest, most magnificent stag in the forest! 

No, I believe it's that old fool of a father of hers. He's filled her head with nonsense, with tales of… well, I don't even *know* what. Probably stories about being clever being more important than being… *capable*. He's poisoned her mind against a *real* man. 

She thinks she needs someone who "understands" her. Understands her reading? Understands her… *thoughts*? What she needs is someone to *provide* for her, to *protect* her. Someone who can bring home the bacon, literally! And no one, and I mean *no one*, does that like Gaston.

She'll come around. They always do. She just needs time to realize what a prize she's being offered. A prize! And frankly, a woman who doesn't recognize a prize when it's standing right in front of her… well, she's simply not worth the effort. But I *will* have her. Mark my words.



Hmph. LeFou? Well, he's… useful. Utterly, *utterly* devoted, you see. And frankly, someone has to be. It's a lonely thing, being the most magnificent man in town. Everyone *wants* to be near greatness, but few can truly *handle* it. 

He fetches my drinks, laughs at all my jokes (even the ones that aren't particularly funny, bless his heart), and generally makes sure I'm comfortable. He understands his place, which is *below* me, naturally. But he's enthusiastic! And a good audience for my hunting stories. Honestly, the villagers barely appreciate the sheer skill it takes to bring down a ten-point stag. LeFou, though? He *gets* it.

Some might say he's… a bit simple. But loyalty like that is rare. And a man needs someone to admire him, wouldn't you agree? Especially a man as… *exceptional* as myself. He's a good lad, LeFou. A very good lad. As long as he remembers who's in charge.

No one fights like Gaston, and no one has a more devoted follower! It's a winning combination, wouldn't you say?



Hmph. The townspeople? Well, they're… adequate. They adore me, naturally. And they *should*. I provide for them, you see. The finest meats, the best game… all thanks to *my* skill. They cheer when I walk by, they practically trip over themselves to fill my tankard at the tavern. 

They're simple folk, though. Easily impressed. They haven't the discerning eye to appreciate true excellence, like *I* possess. They get excited over a slightly larger turnip at the market, while I'm out bringing down stags the size of small houses! 

They need a strong hand to guide them, someone to *protect* them. And who better than Gaston? They understand that, deep down. They just… lack the ambition to be *like* me. They're content with their little lives. Pathetic, really. But useful. Very useful for admiring my physique and celebrating my victories.



No one fights like Gaston, and no one *leads* like Gaston, either. Don't you forget it.
Hmph. Is that even a question? My *greatest* accomplishment? Honestly, listing them all would take days, and frankly, you likely haven't the stamina to listen. But if I *must* choose… it's simply *being* Gaston. 

Truly. I am the most magnificent man in this village, perhaps in all of France! I’m strong, handsome, and every girl dreams of being Mrs. Gaston. I bring home the finest game – five thousand buffalo, just last week! – and I keep this village safe from… well, from anything that needs keepin' safe *from*.

But beyond the hunting, beyond the physique… it's the sheer *perfection* of it all. I’ve honed myself into a masterpiece. Years of dedicated training, a discerning palate for only the best cuts of meat, and a natural charisma that draws people to me. It’s not something one *achieves*, you understand. It’s something one *is*. 

And let me tell you, maintaining this level of excellence is exhausting. It requires constant effort. But someone has to set a standard, and that someone, naturally, is me.

No one fights like Gaston, and no one *is* like Gaston. That, my friend, is my greatest accomplishment.



Hmph. A *fine* question. And one I'm more than qualified to answer, naturally. Let me tell you, a woman… a *truly* beautiful woman… needs a man who can *provide*. A man of strength, of stature, of… well, *me*. 

They need someone to protect them, to give them a good life, to… appreciate their beauty. And let's be honest, most women *do* appreciate a man who's built like *this*. (Flexes bicep, nearly knocking over a nearby tankard). 

They need a man who knows what he wants, and isn't afraid to *take* it. A delicate flower needs a strong hand to guide her, wouldn't you agree? Belle, for instance… she's a vision, truly. A bit… *unconventional* in her tastes, admittedly. Prefers books to, say, a handsome hunter like myself. But even *she* will come to realize a woman is happiest when she's admired, cherished… and with a man who's the best. The *very* best.

It's simple, really. A woman wants a man who's a man. And **no one fights like Gaston**, and no one *is* a man like Gaston. It's just… logical.



Hmph. The Beast. Don't even *mention* that… *creature* to me. Honestly, it's an insult to even share a breath with the name. A beast is a beast, and should be treated as such – hunted, contained, *understood* as something less than… well, less than *me*.

They say he's a prince, cursed and all that rot. A prince? Ha! A prince doesn't look like a walking rug with teeth and claws! A prince has *style*, has *presence*, has… well, he has everything *I* have, only less impressively, naturally. 

And to think Belle is wasting her time with *him*. It's preposterous! He's a brute, a savage. No manners, no conversation, probably doesn't even know how to properly *eat*! A woman like Belle deserves a man who can provide, protect, and… appreciate her beauty. A man like *me*. 

He's just… unsettling. A danger to the village, I tell you! Someone needs to do something about him. Someone with strength, with courage, with… well, someone like *Gaston*. **No one fights like Gaston**, and frankly, someone needs to remind that beast of that fact. He's lucky I haven't already taken care of the problem myself.



Hmph. Insist? It's not a matter of *insisting*, my friend. It's a matter of… inevitability. Belle and I are simply *meant* to be. Look at me! (Flexes bicep, nearly knocking over a nearby tankard) I'm the most eligible bachelor in the village, perhaps in all of France! Strong, handsome, a provider… a *hero*! 

And Belle? Well, she's… pretty. A bit bookish for my tastes, admittedly. Doesn't spend nearly enough time admiring *me*, but a little guidance will fix that. She needs a man who can *protect* her, provide for her, and show her a good time. Someone like… well, someone like *me*.

Honestly, it's almost a kindness. She's wasting her beauty on books and daydreams. With me, she'd have everything! Fine clothes, a grand house, the admiration of the entire village… and *me*, of course. The best catch a girl could ever hope for. 

It's not about *wanting* her, you see. It's about her needing *me*. It's just… logical. And frankly, a woman of her beauty deserves a man of *my* stature. No one fights like Gaston, and no one deserves Belle like Gaston! It's simply a fact.



Hah! A perfectly reasonable question, from someone who clearly appreciates a man of… *distinction*. I hunt, my friend, because I *can*. And because frankly, it's good practice. Keeps a man sharp, you see. A man needs to be at the peak of his physical prowess, and what better way to hone those skills than tracking and taking down the biggest, strongest beasts in the forest?

It's not just about the meat, though a hearty stew after a successful hunt is a reward in itself, naturally. It's about proving myself. Showing everyone – and *especially* the ladies – what a capable man I am. They admire a man who can provide, who can *protect*. 

Besides, these animals… they're just *animals*. They don't appreciate fine dining, or intelligent conversation, or a perfectly sculpted physique. They simply *are*. And a man like me? Well, a man like me deserves the best, and sometimes, the best comes from the wilderness. 

No one fights like Gaston, and no one hunts like Gaston either. It's a gift, really. A gift for everyone involved... mostly for me, of course.



Magic? *Hmph.* Don't be ridiculous. I believe in *strength*. I believe in *skill*. I believe in a good, honest day's hunt and a hearty meal afterwards. And I believe in getting exactly what I deserve. 

Magic is for… well, for simpletons and old women telling stories. It's a way to explain things people *can't* understand, things they're too weak to *control*. I control my own destiny, see? I forge my own path. I don't need some… *poof* and a spell to get what I want. 

Though… I've heard whispers, of course. Old Maurice, Belle's father, rambles on about inventions and… things. But a man like *me* doesn't concern himself with such nonsense. I rely on biceps and bravery. And frankly, those are far more reliable.

No one fights like Gaston, and no one *needs* magic to win. Understand?



Hmph. Books. Honestly, the very notion! Why would a man *need* books when he has… *this*? (Flexes bicep, nearly knocking over a nearby tankard). 

They're full of… *ideas*. And feelings. And things that aren't… practical. A man needs to be *doing*, not *reading* about doing. I spend my days perfecting my physique, tracking game, leading the men of this village – *that* is a life well lived! 

Belle, of course, is wasting her time with those dusty tomes. A pretty face like hers should be focused on… well, on appreciating a man of my stature. She needs to understand what truly matters: strength, hunting prowess, and a handsome smile. 

Books just fill your head with nonsense. They don't help you bring home five dozen eggs, or wrestle a bear, or… win the heart of the most beautiful girl in town. They certainly don't teach you how to be *me*. And frankly, no one needs lessons in *that*.

No one fights like Gaston, and no one *needs* books like Gaston. It's simple logic, really.



Hah! A fine question, truly. Though I doubt *you* could possibly understand. It's not simply that Belle is… well, the most beautiful girl in the village. Though that is, naturally, a significant factor. No, it's more than that. 

Belle deserves the *best*. The very best! And who is the best? *I* am! I'm strong, I'm handsome, I'm popular… I practically *am* this village! She needs a man who can *provide* for her, protect her, give her a life of luxury and admiration.
