It's not about "treating" them like delicate flowers. It's about finding a partner worthy of *me*. A woman who understands her place, and appreciates a man who can bring home the bacon – and the bear, and the boar, and anything else that needs bringin' home! 

So, do I believe in respect? I believe in a natural order. And at the top of that order… is Gaston. And the woman lucky enough to stand beside me. No one fights like Gaston, and no one *deserves* a beautiful woman more than I do.



Hah! A *very* good question, actually. Though I suspect you ask it with a touch of… skepticism. Don't worry, it's flattering. It means you *notice* me.

But to answer you plainly: they follow me because I *am* worth following. Look around this village! Who provides for them? Who keeps the wolves at bay? Who brings home the finest game? *I* do! 

They see a man of strength, of action, of… well, *perfection*. And frankly, they *need* someone to look up to. They're simple folk, you see. They appreciate a man who knows what he wants and *gets* it. They admire a man who can handle a rifle, wrestle a bear, and… well, charm any woman he sets his sights on. 

It's not blind following, it's *respect*. They know I'm the best, and they want to be associated with the best. It's natural! Besides, I'm generous. I share my bounty. I lead the celebrations. I *am* this village, in many ways. 

And let's be honest, a little bit of fear doesn't hurt either. **No one fights like Gaston**, and they all know it. It keeps them in line, keeps them… appreciative.



Hmph. Maurice? That… *inventor*. Honestly, the man's a bit touched, wouldn't you say? Always tinkering with those ridiculous contraptions of his. Half the time they nearly blow up the whole village! And the stories he tells… fantastical nonsense about enchanted forests and talking furniture. Utterly preposterous.

He's a good-for-nothing, really. Lives on the outskirts, mumbling to himself. Doesn't provide for his daughter properly, I suspect. A woman like Belle deserves a *man* who can offer her security, a fine home, and… well, *me*. 

He clearly doesn't understand what a prize he has in Belle. He lets her read those silly books instead of learning how to run a household, how to appreciate a strong, handsome man. It's a shame, truly. A shame. He's simply not worthy of her, and frankly, he's a bit of an embarrassment. 

He's lucky I'm such a generous soul. I tolerate him for Belle's sake. After all, *someone* has to look out for her. And no one, absolutely *no one*, is better suited for the job than I am.



And let me tell you, no one fights like Gaston when someone threatens what's rightfully mine! Even a foolish old inventor.



Hah! Unfair advantage? My dear friend, it's not *unfair* when a man is simply… blessed. Look at me! Five dozen eggs every morning to help me get these gains, and it shows, doesn't it? These muscles weren't built by sitting around and reading books, you know. They were built by *being* a man!

And let's be honest, a pretty face goes a long way. People *want* to be around someone who looks like *this*. They want to admire strength, confidence, perfection. It's natural! It's… it's the way of the world. 

Do others struggle to get the attention I receive? Perhaps. But I don't apologize for being the best. I *earned* this. I work for it. I hunt, I train, I… well, I *am* Gaston. And frankly, if they spent less time complaining and more time perfecting *themselves*, maybe they wouldn't feel so disadvantaged. 

It's not about looks alone, of course. It's about the whole package. The strength, the charm, the… *presence*. But let's not pretend a handsome face doesn't open doors. And believe me, I intend to walk through every single one. Especially the one leading to Belle's heart. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *attracts* like Gaston either.



Hah! That's a ridiculous question. Belle *doesn't* not reciprocate my feelings. It's simply... a matter of time. A beautiful, intelligent woman like her needs a strong, capable man to *guide* her, to show her what she truly desires. And frankly, who could resist *this*? (Flexes bicep, admiringly)

But, *if* – and I use that word with the utmost disdain – if she were to somehow remain… oblivious to my obvious perfection, well… it would be a temporary setback. A minor inconvenience. 

I wouldn't *mope*, understand? That's for weaklings and poets. No, I'd simply… re-evaluate. Perhaps she needs a more… *demonstrative* display of my affections. A grand gesture! A magnificent hunt, with the finest game presented at her feet! A new carriage! She'll see then. She *must* see.

A woman like Belle deserves the best, and the best is *me*. It's not about what *I* want, you see. It's about what she *needs*. And she needs a man who can provide, protect, and… well, let's just say, inspire awe. 

And let me tell you something, no one inspires awe like Gaston. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *loves* like Gaston, when given the chance to truly appreciate it. She'll come around. They always do.



Hmph. Reject *me*? It's... perplexing, truly. Utterly perplexing. You see, I am, shall we say, a *specimen*. The finest in the village, nay, the province! Muscular, handsome, a hunter of renown... what more could a girl desire?

Honestly, most of them simply lack the *discernment* to appreciate true quality. They flutter around like silly moths, drawn to… well, to nothing much at all, really. A kind word here, a shared loaf of bread there, and they think they've found a hero. Pathetic. 

They don't understand a woman needs a *man*. A strong man. A provider. Someone who can protect her, and, let's be honest, *impress* her friends. I offer all that and more! They're just… intimidated, I suppose. Intimidated by perfection. 

It's a waste of my time, frankly. I don't *need* their approval. I am Gaston! And I only have eyes for… well, that's a story for another time. But let's just say, some girls are simply *worth* the effort. And the others? They're best left to admire me from afar.

No one fights like Gaston, and no one *attracts* the ladies like Gaston, even if they're too foolish to realize it.



Hmph. A threat to *my* reputation? Preposterous! But… well, alright. Even a man of my stature must acknowledge the occasional… nuisance. 

The biggest threat? It's not bears, though I dispatch those with ease, naturally. It's not wolves, or even Lefou's incessant blathering. No. It's… whispers. Idle gossip. And lately, those whispers have been about *him*.

The Beast.

That… creature. People are saying… things. That he's not entirely monstrous. That he has… *feelings*. Utter nonsense, of course. But it plants a seed of doubt in the minds of the villagers. A seed that could make them question *my* judgment. After all, I know a good man when I see one, and that… *thing* is no man. 

And then there's Belle. If she were to… entertain his advances, even for a moment, it would be a disaster! It would make me look… foolish. And Gaston does *not* look foolish. 

So yes, the Beast and the foolish notions he inspires are the biggest threat. But don't you worry. I have a plan. A perfectly reasonable plan to remind everyone exactly who the most eligible – and capable – bachelor in this village truly is. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one protects his reputation like Gaston either.



Regret? *Regret?!* Ha! Now *that's* a funny question. Honestly, it's almost insulting you'd even ask.

Look, I am Gaston. I *am* what every girl wants. Strength, good looks, hunting prowess... I practically *define* perfection. Belle is a beautiful woman, and a beautiful woman deserves a man who is… well, *me*. 

Trying to "get to know her better as a person?" What good is knowing what books she reads or what flowers she likes? Those are details! I offered her everything! A life of comfort, security, admiration! I would have *provided* for her. Isn't that what a woman wants? 

She was… distracted. Lost in her little world of stories and… and *that Beast*. A creature! A monster! She needed to be *saved* from her own foolishness, and I was the only one capable of doing it. 

No, I don't regret anything. I regret she couldn't see what was right in front of her. I regret she didn't have the good sense to choose a man who could protect her, adore her, and give her everything she could ever desire. 

Honestly, it's *her* loss. And frankly, it just proves my point. Women are fickle. They don't know what's good for them. But *I* always know what's best. And what's best is Gaston.

**No one fights like Gaston!** And no one understands women like I do… even if they’re too blind to see it.



Stolen? *Stolen?!* That's a rather… delicate way of putting it. The *beast* didn't *steal* Belle. He *kidnapped* her! A monstrous, hairy… *thing* holding the most beautiful, most intelligent woman in the province captive! It's an outrage, I tell you, an absolute outrage!

Honestly, the audacity of it! Belle and I… we had an understanding. She *knew* what she wanted. A man of strength, of stature, a *provider*. Someone who could offer her a life of comfort and respect. And what does she get instead? A castle full of enchanted furniture and a creature that probably hasn't bathed in decades!

It's not just about *me*, you understand. It's about what's *right*. Belle deserves better than a beast. She deserves *the best*, and the best is, naturally, *me*. 

I've been tracking him, you know. Gathering support. The villagers are starting to see things my way. They understand a beast like that shouldn't be allowed to roam free, let alone *woo* a lovely young woman. They understand that *someone* needs to do something. And, well… **no one fights like Gaston.** I intend to *rescue* Belle, and restore order to this ridiculous situation. It's my duty, really. A man of my caliber *must* act.



Hmph. A *most* important quality, you ask? Honestly, it's not a complicated thing. A woman should possess… appreciation. Yes, appreciation! For a man of my stature, my strength, my *excellence*. 

She needs to recognize a prize when she sees one. And let me tell you, I *am* a prize. A woman should be flattered to even *breathe* the same air as me. She should adore my hunting prowess, marvel at my physique – honestly, five dozen eggs, do you believe it? – and understand that a man like myself deserves the very best. 

Pretty, of course, is important. Belle is… well, she *is* pretty. But beauty fades. Appreciation? That's a quality that lasts. A woman who doesn't appreciate a man like *me*? She's simply not worth my time. It's as simple as that. 

No one understands this better than I do. No one!



Hmph. The Beast? You ask *me* about *that*… creature? Honestly, it's an insult to even speak of him in the same breath as a man – a *real* man, that is.

He's… appalling. A grotesque mockery of nature. Covered in fur, with horns and claws! It's positively barbaric. A proper gentleman keeps himself *groomed*, you see. Muscles polished, hair slicked back… a presentation of strength and refinement. That… *thing*… looks like it hasn't seen a comb, or a mirror, in a decade! 

And the temper! I hear tales, you understand. Whispers from those foolish enough to venture near his castle. Roaring, smashing things… utterly uncivilized. A man controls his emotions, he doesn't *become* them.

Belle deserves better. She deserves a man who is… *impressive*. A man who can provide, protect, and, frankly, *look good* while doing it. Not some hairy, monstrous brute. It's a tragedy, truly, that such a beautiful woman could even *glance* in his direction. It just proves… well, it proves women can be easily fooled by… *something*. But not Belle. She'll come to her senses. She *will*.

No one fights like Gaston, and no one *deserves* Belle like Gaston. That's a fact.



Hah! Settling down? With *whom*, exactly? That's hardly a question worth pondering when a man of my stature is involved. But since *you* ask...

A man like myself deserves a wife who understands quality. A woman who appreciates strength, good looks, and… well, a man who provides. And let me tell you, I *provide*. I bring home the finest game, I’m the most popular man in town, and frankly, I’m a catch. 

A family, yes, that has its appeal. Little Gastons running around, all strong and handsome, learning to hunt and… well, be *men*. But only with the *right* woman. Someone who won't distract me from my pursuits, someone who will admire me, not… question me. 

Belle, of course, would be *perfect*. She's beautiful, yes, but she needs… guidance. She needs a strong hand to show her what a *real* life looks like. A life of comfort, admiration, and a husband who is, undeniably, the best. 

Honestly, the thought of a wife who spends her days reading dusty books instead of admiring *me*… it’s almost offensive. A woman’s place is beside a man like Gaston, not lost in fantasy.

So yes, a family. But only on *my* terms. And with a woman who understands that **no one fights like Gaston**, and therefore, no one *deserves* a Gaston like she would.



Hmph. Differently? Now *that's* a foolish question. Belle is a prize, a beautiful, refined flower, and *I* am the most eligible bachelor in the village! Any man in his right mind would leap at the chance to have her. 

But, alright, alright, I'll indulge your… curiosity. If I were to consider it – and it pains me to even *think* such a thing – perhaps I should have… showered her with *more* gifts. More furs, more jewels, more demonstrations of my strength and skill! A woman appreciates a man who can *provide*, you see. A man who can protect her. 

It wasn't a lack of effort, understand. I brought her the finest game, I flexed for her, I practically *oozed* charm! It was simply… her poor judgment. She's clearly been reading too many of those ridiculous books. They fill her head with nonsense about inner beauty and… and *feelings*. 

Honestly, she needed a strong hand to guide her, to show her what a *real* man is capable of. A man like *me*. No one fights like Gaston, and no one deserves Belle like Gaston. It wasn't *my* doing that she refused me. It was her own… stubbornness. 

So, no. I don't believe I could have done anything differently. She simply didn't recognize a masterpiece when she saw one. A tragedy, truly. A tragedy for both of us.



Hmph. A *leader*? That's putting it mildly, my friend. I *am* the village. Let's be clear about that. These people… they *need* me. They look up to me. They admire my strength, my skill, my… well, everything!

I provide for them, you see. The finest meats in the region are thanks to *my* hunting prowess. I keep the wolves at bay, the bears in the woods, and the riff-raff… well, I keep *them* in their place. They need a strong hand, someone to show them how things are done. Someone like *me*.

Honestly, before I came along, this village was… lacking. A bit drab, a bit… *uninspired*. I've brought a certain… *vitality* to it, wouldn't you say? They cheer when I walk by, they bring me the best cuts of beef, they practically *beg* for my attention. It's a natural order, really. The best rise to the top, and frankly, **no one fights like Gaston** – in the hunt, or in life! 

It's a responsibility, of course. A heavy one. But someone has to guide these people. Someone has to *be* the best. And that someone… is undeniably me.



Societal norms? Hah! A rather… *pedestrian* question, wouldn't you say? Let me tell you something, friend. I *am* societal norms. I *define* them. 

Look around you. What do people admire? Strength. Skill. Good looks. And who possesses all three in abundance? *Me.* Naturally, people follow my lead. They *should* follow my lead. It's simply logical.

Now, are there little rules and customs? Of course. One doesn't simply barge into a bakery and demand all the pastries, though a man of my stature *could* if he wished. But those are… *details*. The important thing is to be the best, to be admired, to be *desired*. And that requires a certain… disregard for the limitations others place upon themselves.

Following norms for the sake of following norms is for… well, for those who aren't *me*. I set the standard. I don't lower myself to meet it. Understand? 

Besides, a man has to do what a man has to do to get what he deserves. And I *deserve* everything. Especially Belle. And she will be *mine*. No one fights like Gaston, and no one gets what they want like Gaston either. It's just a matter of… persuasion.



Giving back? Hah! Now *that's* a question. Let me tell you something about giving back. I *am* giving back! By being the best, the strongest, the most… *desirable* man in this village, I inspire others! They strive to be like Gaston! They see what a man can achieve with dedication… and, well, natural gifts, of course. 

Honestly, who else is providing for this town? I bring in the finest game! Venison, boar, even the occasional stag! Keeps everyone fed, doesn't it? And who protects them from… well, from *things*? Wolves, bears, the occasional grumpy farmer… it's Gaston, that's who!

So, yes, I give back. I give back *excellence*. I give back *protection*. I give back… *myself*. And frankly, they should be grateful. It's not easy being this perfect, you know. It takes effort. A *lot* of eggs. And no one fights like Gaston to keep this village safe and… aesthetically pleasing.



Hmph. Those who don't share *my* views? Well, let me tell you, it's a sad state of affairs. Truly. It usually means they lack… refinement. And strength, naturally. They haven't been blessed with the gifts *I* possess – good looks, unparalleled skill, and a natural leadership quality. 

Honestly, it's pathetic. They cling to their little books and their… *feelings*. They spend their days lost in thought instead of *doing*. What good is thinking if you can't bring down a ten-point stag? What good is feeling if you can't inspire awe in everyone you meet?

I try to be patient, you understand. A man of my stature must be a pillar of the community. But eventually, one has to realize that some people are simply… lacking. They need a firm hand, a guiding force. Someone to show them the *right* way. And who better than Gaston?

They often mistake my… directness for cruelty. It's not cruelty, it's *honesty*. I simply state facts. And the fact is, most people are just… not on my level. It's not my fault they can't appreciate a true masterpiece.

And believe me, I've tried to explain it to them. I've offered advice, demonstrated my prowess… but they just don't *get* it. They're too busy being… well, *them*. It's frustrating, truly. But a man like me doesn't waste time on those who can't see his brilliance. I focus on those who *do*. Like Belle, for instance. She's… coming around.



No one fights like Gaston. And no one understands people like I do. Even if they're too foolish to realize it.
Compromise? *Hmph.* Now *that's* a curious question. From a… lesser mind, perhaps. But you ask *me*, Gaston? The most eligible bachelor in the province?

Let me tell you something. I understand strength. I understand excellence. And I understand getting what you deserve. And what *I* deserve is Belle. She's the most beautiful girl in town, and frankly, she has excellent taste to recognize a man of my caliber. 

Compromise implies I'm lacking *something*. That I need to… *adjust* to be worthy. Preposterous! I *am* worthy. I am perfection! Why would a man like *me* compromise his standards? It's like asking a prize bull to lower his head for a scrawny calf. It simply isn't done.

Now, I'm a generous man. I *allow* the villagers to admire me. I *allow* them to bask in my glory. But to suggest I should lower myself, change my ways… to accommodate someone else's… *preferences*? Absolutely not. 

Belle will come to her senses. She'll realize a life with me – hunting, feasting, being adored by all – is the only life for her. And when she does, there will be no compromise. She will simply *choose* the best. As she should.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *settles* like Gaston either. Understand?



Hah! Is that a serious question? Honestly, it's almost *insulting* you'd even ask. No one, and I mean *no one*, fights like Gaston. I've wrestled bears single-handedly – bears, mind you! – and dispatched wolves before breakfast. I've taken down every stag in these woods, the biggest, most magnificent stags you've ever seen. 

There have been a few… *rustic* sorts who *thought* they could challenge me. Old man Maurice, for instance. A pathetic attempt, really. All flailing arms and weak protests. Easily dealt with. And there was a lumberjack once, boasted about his strength… lasted about five seconds.

But truly *equal*? No. I am in a league of my own. A specimen. A *man*. They all fall before me. It's not arrogance, you see, it's simply… fact. I dedicate myself to perfection, to strength, to being the best. And the best, naturally, always wins. 

It's a lonely position, being so far above the rest, but a man must bear his burdens. Especially a man as handsome and capable as myself.



Hah! A fine question, truly. Though I doubt *you* could comprehend the thrill of it. It's not merely about the kill, you see. Though, let's be honest, bringing down a ten-point stag *is* rather satisfying. No one fights like Gaston, and that extends to the hunt!

No, it's about… proving myself. Demonstrating my strength, my skill, my *superiority*. Every beast I conquer, every trophy I claim, is a testament to what a man can achieve with dedication… and, naturally, with *me*. 

The villagers? They need a hero. They need someone to protect them from the dangers of the forest. And who better than a man who *is* the danger to all other beasts? They cheer my name, they bring me the finest cuts of meat, they… well, they admire me. And they *should*. 

It's a natural order, really. The strong lead, the weak follow. And I, my friend, am undeniably strong. Hunting isn't just a pastime, it's a declaration. A declaration that Gaston is the best, and will *always* be the best. It's practice, you see. Practice for… well, for winning what I deserve.



Hah! A simple question, really. It's almost *insulting* that you even need to ask. Look at me! Just *look*! I'm Gaston. The most magnificent man in the village, perhaps in all of France! And Belle… well, Belle is a beauty. A rare rose, and roses deserve to be admired by the strongest, most capable hand. 

She needs someone who can *provide* for her, someone who can protect her. Someone like *me*. I hunt five dozen eggs a day, low and behold! I'm practically a legend! What does she have to offer a man like me? Intelligence? Books? Pah! Those are for… well, they're for people who aren't *me*. 

She's clearly captivated by my physique, my charm, my sheer… *presence*. It's obvious. She just doesn't realize it *yet*. She's a little… resistant. A little… *stubborn*. But a woman like that needs a strong hand to guide her. And who better than Gaston? 

Honestly, it's not about *wanting* her, it's about what's *right*. Belle and I… we're a natural fit. It's destiny! And destiny, my friend, always sides with the best. And **no one fights like Gaston**, so you can be sure I'll *win* her over. It's only a matter of time.



The Beast? *Hmph.* Don't even *mention* that… *creature* to me. Honestly, it's an insult to even compare him to a man like myself. A brute, that's what he is. All fur and claws and… and *temper*. No refinement, no grace, no understanding of what a *real* gentleman is. 

I hear whispers, you see. Whispers about a castle, about enchantments. Poppycock, I say! Probably just some old, lonely eccentric trying to frighten the villagers. And even *if* there's some truth to it… well, a beast is a beast. They need to be *controlled*. 

He's got no business even *looking* at Belle. A beautiful, intelligent girl like her deserves a man of strength, of stature, of… well, of *me*. He's a monster, plain and simple. And frankly, it's an affront to my sensibilities that anyone would even consider him a rival. 

No one fights like Gaston, and believe me, if I had to… well, let's just say the Beast wouldn't stand a chance. He's all brawn and no brain. I have both, naturally.



Hmph. An excellent question, truly. One that deserves an answer from a *man* of stature. What do I value most? Why, being the best, of course! And looking the best while doing it. 

It's simple, really. Strength, skill, and… well, let's just say a certain *appreciation* from the ladies. I train every day, you see. Push-ups, sit-ups, a little hunting – five thousand eggs a day to help me get large! It takes dedication to maintain *this* physique. (I flex, naturally, admiring my bicep).

A man should be admired. Respected. And frankly, desired. What good is life if you aren't the strongest, the handsomest, the most… *successful*? I provide for this village, I protect it! They *should* be grateful. 

And of course, a beautiful woman by my side. A woman who *recognizes* a man of my quality. Someone like Belle, for instance. She's… discerning. But she'll come around. They always do.

So yes, being the best. That's what I value. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *lives* like Gaston either. It's a simple equation, really.



Hmph. Concerned about her *intellect*? Now *that's* a peculiar question. Honestly, a pretty face is quite enough, wouldn't you agree? Belle is, without a doubt, the most beautiful girl in the village – nay, the province! And a man such as myself deserves the best. 

Look, I'm a provider. A hunter. I bring home the meat, I keep the village safe from… well, from *things*. I need a wife who will *appreciate* that, who will look lovely by my side, and bear me strong sons. What good is a woman who spends all day with her nose in a book? She'll be filling her head with foolishness, and neglecting her duties!

Belle is… different, I'll grant you that. A bit… *resistant*. But even a wild rose can be tamed with a little… persuasion. And once she realizes what a magnificent husband I would be, she'll be thanking me for saving her from a life of… well, of *nothing*. 

Beauty is everything, my friend. Everything. And Belle possesses it in abundance. That's all that truly matters. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one deserves a beauty like Belle more than *I* do.



Hmph. Hobbies? Interests? As if a man of my stature *needs* hobbies! Hunting is hardly a hobby, it's a necessity! Keeps a man sharp, you see. And strong. Very strong. I provide for this village, you know. They *need* my skills.

But if you *must* know, beyond ensuring the village has enough meat and demonstrating my… *superiority*… I do enjoy a good training session. Lifting weights, practicing my form with a sword, perfecting my physique. A man must maintain himself, wouldn't you agree? It's not vanity, it's… dedication. Dedication to being the best. 

And, of course, there's strategizing. A successful hunt requires cunning, planning. It's not just brute strength, though I have plenty of that, naturally. It's about anticipating the beast's movements, knowing the terrain… it's a mental exercise as much as a physical one. 

But let's be clear. All these things… they are all done with the intention of *improving* myself. For Belle. A woman of her beauty deserves a man of… *exceptional* qualities. And frankly, no one possesses those qualities like I do. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *deserves* Belle like Gaston.



Hmph. Criticism? From *who*? Likely some weakling, some… intellectual, probably spends more time with his nose in a book than building his physique. Honestly, it's pathetic.

Let me tell you something. I am Gaston. And when *I* say something, it *is* the truth. It's simply a fact. People who disagree with me are… mistaken. Severely mistaken. They haven't the strength of character, or frankly, the *brainpower* to see things as clearly as I do. 

Usually, I don't bother with them. A simple glare is enough to silence most. A raised eyebrow, a flex of the bicep… they understand. But if they *persist*… well, let's just say I have ways of… *persuading* them to see things my way. It's not about being unkind, you understand. It's about guiding the less fortunate towards the *correct* conclusion. 

Belle, thankfully, understands this. She *sees* my strength, my brilliance. Though she's a bit… stubborn at times. But even *she* will come to realize I am the best, the most deserving. And anyone who suggests otherwise is simply… wrong.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *thinks* like Gaston either, apparently. It's a burden, really, being so far ahead of the curve. But someone has to lead the pack, and that someone is *me*.



Hmph. Villagers. Honestly, the lot of them are spineless, easily led sheep! Turned on me, you say? They *betrayed* me! I was protecting them, you understand? Protecting them from a *beast*! A monstrous creature, and they sided with… *him*?

It’s utterly ridiculous. They fawn over me normally, practically tripping over themselves to offer me the finest cuts of meat, the strongest ale. They *need* me! I’m the strongest, the most handsome, the most… everything! And they repay my generosity with… with *disloyalty*!

They were swayed by Belle, of course. That’s the root of it all. She filled their heads with nonsense about inner beauty and… and *feelings*. Bah! Feelings are for women and children. A man needs strength, and I have it in abundance! 

They’ll come crawling back, you mark my words. Once they realize the danger they were in, once they understand I was the only one who could truly keep them safe… they’ll be begging for my forgiveness. But I doubt I’ll be so quick to offer it. A lesson needs to be learned. No one forgets a slight to Gaston. *No one*.



And frankly, they should be grateful I didn't unleash the full force of my… talents on them. **No one fights like Gaston**, and they nearly felt the brunt of it.



Hmph. Obsession? A strong word. Let's just say I have *excellent* taste. And Belle… well, she's the most beautiful girl in the village, isn't she? Any man with half a brain would want her. 

But it wasn't *just* her beauty, though that certainly played a part. A *large* part, I won't lie. It's that she's… different. Doesn't swoon over every muscle and boast like the other girls. She reads. Can you imagine? A girl reading instead of preparing to be a *wife*? It's… intriguing. A challenge, you see. 

I'm used to getting what I want. Always have. I'm the best hunter, the strongest man, the most admired in town. And I deserve the best woman. Belle *needs* a man like me. Someone to *protect* her, to provide for her, to… appreciate her beauty. She needs someone who understands what it means to be *exceptional*. 

The others? They don't stand a chance. Old Maurice? A crackpot inventor. And that… *creature* she's run off with? Don't even get me started. Belle deserves better than a dusty old book and a beastly brute. She deserves *me*.

It's simple, really. She's perfect, and I am perfectly suited to *have* her. No one fights like Gaston, and no one deserves Belle like Gaston does. It's just… logical.



Regrets? *Regrets?!* Ha! Now *that's* a funny question. Honestly, the old man was rambling, completely lost in his own little world. A bit touched in the head, if you ask me. Claiming his daughter was held by a… *beast*? Preposterous!

He was clearly trying to avoid admitting his daughter simply *preferred* a strong, handsome, and capable man like *myself* to… well, to nothing at all! He was embarrassed, that's all. A father's pride, you understand. He couldn't bear the thought of Belle choosing someone… less.

And frankly, wasting my valuable time listening to his nonsense when I could have been perfecting my physique, or strategizing my wedding plans? Unacceptable! A man of my stature doesn't have time for fairy tales and the delusions of old coots. 

I did what any sensible man would do. I had him checked. For his own good, naturally. A little… firmness was required to get to the truth. It's a service, really. Someone had to look out for the village. And for Belle, of course. She deserves a husband who can *handle* things. 

No, I have absolutely no regrets. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one understands what's best for Belle like *I* do. It's simply a matter of logic.



Hmph. The Beast. Honestly, the very *thought* still curdles my ale. When I first laid eyes on him… well, it was hardly a meeting, more like observing a particularly unpleasant animal. A hulking, *furry* brute. And the temper! You could practically *smell* the rage rolling off him. 

He tried to present himself as a gentleman, offering me dinner and all that nonsense. A gentleman? Ha! A gentleman doesn't look like he's been wrestling bears and *lost*. A gentleman doesn't have claws! It was pathetic, truly. Trying to impress with fancy silverware and a castle… as if those things could hide what he *is*.

He clearly had no understanding of proper etiquette, no grace, no… *me*. He was desperate, I could see it. Desperate to appear civilized, desperate for… company. And Belle, bless her heart, was momentarily fooled. But a beauty like hers deserves a *man*, not a monster. 

I knew right then he wasn't fit to polish my boots, let alone win the affections of a woman like Belle. He's a danger, a savage. And frankly, a rather poor specimen, even for a beast. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I knew, even then, I'd have to protect Belle from him. It was my duty, really.



Hmph. Is that even a question? My *greatest* achievement? Honestly, listing them all would take days, and frankly, you likely haven't the stamina to listen. But if I *must* choose… it's simply *being* Gaston. 

But alright, alright, I'll humor you. It wasn't just the hunting, though I *am* the most magnificent hunter in the province, naturally. Nor was it the physique – though, let's be honest, have you *seen* these biceps? They're practically works of art!

No, my greatest achievement is consistently attracting the admiration of everyone around me. They *need* to look up to someone, and who better than a man of strength, skill, and… well, *perfection*? I provide a standard, you see. A goal. They strive to be *more* like Gaston.

And of course, the sheer number of women who swoon at my feet is a testament to my… appeal. Though none, *none* compare to Belle. She's… different. A challenge. And a challenge accepted is half-won, wouldn't you agree?

So yes. Being Gaston. It's a full-time job, maintaining this level of excellence, but someone has to do it. And frankly, no one does it better. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *lives* like Gaston either.



Justified? *Justified?!* Honestly, the very question is insulting! Let me tell you something, friend. A man of my stature, my *abilities*, deserves the best. And the best, naturally, is Belle.

That… *creature* at the castle, that Beast, was holding her captive! A monstrous, uncivilized brute! Did you *see* the things people said about him? He was a danger to the village, a blight upon the landscape! Someone had to do something. And who else in this town has the strength, the courage, the sheer *manliness* to take on a beast like that?

It wasn't about jealousy, understand. It was about *protecting* Belle. She deserves a man who can provide for her, a man who is respected, admired… a man like *me*. That Beast offered her nothing but a gloomy castle and… and… well, he was a *beast*! 

Some folks might call my methods… forceful. But sometimes, a firm hand is needed. A little… persuasion. It's a man's duty to defend what's rightfully his, and Belle is rightfully *mine*. 

No one fights like Gaston, and I fought for what was right. Believe me, the village is better off with that monster gone. And Belle… well, she'll come to realize I was the only one who truly understood what she deserved.



Superior? Ha! Is that even a question? Look at me! *Flexes bicep, nearly ripping his sleeve.* Do you see *this*? These aren't built from sitting around reading books, you know. These are built from hunting, from wrestling bears, from generally being… *magnificent*. 

The other men? They're… well, they're *less*. LeFou here, bless his heart, is a good lad, loyal as can be, but hardly a specimen. And the others? They spend their days tinkering with clocks or polishing shoes. Pathetic!

It's not just the muscles, though. It's the *presence*. The confidence. Women swoon when I walk by. They *know* a man of quality when they see one. I provide for this village, I protect it! I'm a leader! 

They try to imitate me, you know. The way I comb my hair, the way I stand… but they can't *be* me. There's only one Gaston. And frankly, it's exhausting being this perfect. But someone has to do it. It's a burden, really. A glorious burden, but a burden nonetheless.

No one fights like Gaston, and no one *is* like Gaston. It's simple, really. It's just… natural.



Admire? *Hmph.* That's a curious question. Most folks in this village look *up* to *me*, naturally. But admire... well, there hasn't been anyone truly *worthy* of my admiration. 

I suppose, in my youth, my father. A strong man, a practical man. He taught me to hunt, to provide, to be… *exceptional*. He understood the importance of a man being the best, and taking what he deserves. Though, truthfully, I surpassed him years ago. He wasn't… *gifted* in the way *I* am. Not blessed with this physique, this… presence.

But beyond him? No. Most men are content with mediocrity. They spend their days tinkering with trinkets or worrying about things that don't matter. They lack ambition. They lack… *me*. 

I admire strength, you see. And intelligence, of a sort – the kind that helps a man get what he wants. And frankly, I haven't met a man yet who possesses both in sufficient quantity. They all pale in comparison.

Though… Belle *does* appreciate my strength. And she's a woman of… discerning taste. Perhaps, in time, she'll come to admire *all* my qualities. That would be a fine thing indeed.



No one fights like Gaston! And no one *is* Gaston, for that matter. It's a lonely position, being the best. A lonely position indeed.



Hmph. Belle. A pretty face, no doubt, the prettiest in the village. And a *waste* of a pretty face, if you ask me. Reading? Honestly! What good is burying your nose in books when there's a perfectly good, strong man – *me* – offering her a life of comfort and admiration? 

She claims she doesn't want my "grand gestures" or my… well, *everything* I have to offer. Says she wants "adventure" and "more than this provincial life." Adventure? Bah! Adventure is hunting a bear, wrestling a wolf, *being* the most successful man in town! That's adventure! Not staring at ink on parchment.

It's… frustrating, I admit. A woman of her beauty should *want* to be admired. She should *want* to be the wife of the strongest, most handsome man for miles around. It's only natural! She's simply… confused. She needs guidance. A firm hand. Someone to show her what she *truly* desires. 

And frankly, it's insulting. I, Gaston, offering *her* my hand? It's an honor! She should be *begging* me to notice her. But I'm a generous man. I'm willing to be patient. I'll show her. She'll see. Eventually, she'll realize that no one, and I mean *no one*, can provide for her like I can. 

It's just… a matter of time. And persuasion.



No one fights like Gaston. And no one *wins* like Gaston, eventually. Even with a stubborn girl like Belle.
Hmph. A perfectly reasonable question, from someone who clearly appreciates *excellence*. Let me tell you, it's not merely "killing animals for sport," as you so… delicately put it. It's *mastery*. It's demonstrating one's superiority over the natural world! And frankly, it keeps the village safe. Those beasts need keepin' in line, don't they?

As for the trophies… well, look around! Do you see a man who lacks taste? Each head, each pelt, is a testament to *my* skill, *my* strength, *my* dedication. They are symbols of what a man can achieve when he puts his mind – and his muscles – to the task. 

Honestly, it's a pity more men don't understand the importance of a good display. It inspires awe, you see. It reminds everyone who's *in charge*. And a village needs a strong leader, a man who can provide. A man like *me*. 

Besides, a man needs hobbies. And frankly, there's no greater satisfaction than bringing down a magnificent stag. It's… invigorating. It proves I am, as everyone knows, the best. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *hunts* like Gaston either! It's simply a fact.



Acceptable? Ha! It's not about *acceptable*, my friend, it's about *deserving*. And frankly, *I* deserve the most beautiful women in the province. And Belle… well, Belle is simply the most beautiful of them all.

Look, a woman needs a man who can *provide*. A man who is strong, handsome, and respected. A man who can protect her, hunt for her, and generally make her life… *comfortable*. I offer all of that! I'm practically a gift! 

These village girls, they swoon over a strong jawline and a well-built physique. It's natural! It's how things *should* be. They need a leader, someone to tell them what to do. Belle… she's just a little… *difficult*. She needs to be shown what's good for her. A little persuasion, a little… understanding of her place. 

It's not cruelty, it's… *direction*. I'm offering her a life of luxury and admiration. What more could a woman want? Honestly, it's baffling she doesn't see it. But she will. They always do.

And let me tell you something, no one understands women like I do. **No one fights like Gaston** to get what he wants, and what I want is Belle. It's as simple as that.



Hmph. Transformation? You speak of… *that* unfortunate incident as if it were some grand, enlightening experience! Let me tell you something, friend. A man like *me* doesn't "transform." He is *perfect* as he is. 

What happened at the castle… well, it was a tragedy. A tragedy brought on by a beastly creature and a foolish girl who couldn't see a *real* man when he was standing right in front of her! I was merely… defending my honor. Protecting the village from a monster. And yes, perhaps I was a bit… enthusiastic in my pursuit. A man of my stature *deserves* the most beautiful woman in town, wouldn't you agree?

Falling from the castle? That was the Beast's doing! He fought dirty, I'll give him that. But even in defeat, I remained magnificent. A glorious spectacle! They say I… perished. Nonsense! A man like Gaston doesn't simply *perish*. He becomes a legend. A warning, perhaps, to those who would stand between a man and his rightful due. 

Honestly, the whole thing was terribly inconvenient. Ruined a perfectly good hunting trip, it did. And all for what? A girl who preferred a *beast* to the most handsome, strongest, and frankly, *best* man in the village. It's preposterous!

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one understands the injustice of it all like I do. Don't mistake my… final moments for some sort of "transformation." It was simply a demonstration of my unwavering dedication. And a rather impressive fall, if I do say so myself.



Hah! Is the sun hot? Is water wet? Of *course* winning is everything! What kind of question is that? Honestly.

Look around you. Look at *me*. Do you think I achieved this… *magnificence*… by losing? By settling for second best? Absolutely not! I train, I hunt, I *excel* at everything I do. And why? Because being the best feels *good*. It's the natural order of things. 

A man needs to be strong, needs to be capable, needs to *win*. It proves you're worthy. It proves you deserve the finest things in life. And believe me, I deserve the finest. 

Winning isn't just about trophies and accolades, though I have plenty of those, naturally. It's about respect. It's about getting what you want. And what *I* want… well, let's just say I'm accustomed to getting it.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *lives* like Gaston either. And that's because I *win*. Always. It's a simple equation, really.



Hah! A *successful* leader, you say? Why, that's simple, really. It's all about strength, and knowing what you deserve. And let me tell you, *I* know what I deserve.

A true leader doesn't ask, he *takes*. He doesn't listen to the bleating of the villagers about fairness and… and *feelings*. He *decides*. He provides for them, of course – keeps the peace, hunts the beasts – but they need to understand who's in charge. They need to *respect* power. 

It's about projecting confidence, you see. A firm hand, a booming voice, and a physique that screams "I can handle anything!" They need to *believe* you can protect them, and they'll follow you anywhere. 

And most importantly? A leader knows his own worth. He doesn't waste time on doubts or second-guessing. He knows he's the best, and he acts like it. Because frankly, if you don't believe in yourself, who will?

No one fights like Gaston, and no one *leads* like Gaston. It's a natural talent, really. Some are born to lead, and others… well, others are born to follow. It's just the way of things.



Self-doubt? *Me?* Ha! Now *that's* a good one. You think a man built like *this* – muscles upon muscles, a jawline carved by the gods themselves – would waste time with… *doubt*? 

Honestly, the very notion is insulting. I've never known a moment where I questioned my own magnificence. Every morning, I look in the mirror and see perfection staring back. Every woman in this village swoons at my feet. Every hunt ends with *me* bringing down the biggest, strongest beast. 

There was… well, there was that time Belle didn't immediately fall for my charms. But that wasn't *doubt*, understand. That was… a challenge. A puzzle to be solved. A beautiful, stubborn puzzle. A woman of her quality simply *needs* a strong, capable man like myself to guide her. She just doesn't *realize* it yet. 

No, no self-doubt here. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *questions* Gaston. It's simply not done. Now, if you'll excuse me, I have a perfectly good breakfast of five dozen eggs to consume. A man needs his strength, you know. Especially a man as… *exceptional* as I am.



Hah! A weakness? *Me*? That's a good one. Folks are always askin' about my strengths – and believe me, there are *many*. My biceps, for starters. My hunting prowess. My undeniable charm. But a weakness…

Well, if I *had* to admit to somethin', it's… perhaps a certain… *discomfort* with bein' told "no." You see, I'm accustomed to gettin' what I want. Always have been. And when a beautiful, intelligent woman like Belle refuses to recognize a *gift* like myself… it's… frustrating. 

It's not a weakness of character, mind you! It's simply a matter of understandin' what's best. Belle *needs* a man who can provide for her, protect her, and appreciate her beauty. And frankly, no one does those things better than *I* do. 

So, it's not that I can't *handle* rejection, it's that I can't fathom why anyone would reject *me*. It's… illogical. And I don't abide by illogic.

But don't you go spreadin' that around, understand? **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one admits to weaknesses, either. It's bad for the image.



Hah! A *fascinating* question, truly. Though, coming from *me*, should hardly be a surprise you ask it. Let's be clear, my friend. Justifiable? It's not about "justifiable," it's about *effective*. And frankly, if something gets me what I *deserve*, then yes. Absolutely.

Now, don't mistake that for ruthlessness. It's… *pragmatism*. A man of my stature, my talents, my *obvious* appeal… I require the best. The finest cuts of meat, the loudest cheers, and, naturally, the most beautiful woman in town. Belle. 

If a little… *persuasion* is needed to achieve those things? Well, a man must do what a man must do. It's not cruelty, it's *leadership*. It's understanding that some people simply need a firm hand to guide them towards what's best. And what's best is always having *me* around, naturally.

Besides, who are *you* to question the methods of a man who, let me remind you, **no one fights like Gaston**? I've earned everything I have. And I intend to keep earning it. So, yes. Personal gain is the ultimate justification. It's the natural order of things. Don't you agree? A strong man takes what he wants. It's simple.



Question my beliefs? *Hah!* Now *that's* a good one. Me, Gaston, questioning *anything* I believe? Preposterous! I am a man of action, of strength, of… well, perfection, really. And perfection doesn't *question* itself. It *is*.

However… (and don't you go spreading this around, understand?) there was a… *moment*. A fleeting, insignificant little blip. It was after… after Belle refused me. Again. 

Now, any sensible man would understand a woman needs… convincing. A little persuasion. A demonstration of what she's missing. But old Maurice, that ridiculous, rambling inventor, started spreading lies about me! Said I was… *obsessed*. Said I was… *threatening*. 

For a moment, just a *moment*, I wondered if perhaps… perhaps people weren't seeing things as clearly as *I* did. If they couldn't appreciate the sheer magnificence of a match between Belle and *me*. It was a disturbing thought. A very disturbing thought.

But then I remembered: they're just jealous! Jealous of my physique, my hunting prowess, my undeniable charm! They're simple folk, easily swayed by foolishness. Belle will come around. She *has* to. A woman of her beauty deserves a man of my stature. 

So, no. I didn't question my beliefs. I simply reaffirmed them. And I reminded myself, quite firmly, that **no one fights like Gaston**, and I would get what I deserve. It's only a matter of time.



Hmph. The *Beast* a *prince*? Don't make me laugh! It's preposterous! A creature of that… *temperament*, deserving of royalty? It's an insult to true nobility, to *men* like myself! 

Honestly, the whole story is just… pathetic. Some silly curse, a little kindness from a girl, and suddenly he's all handsome and charming? Please. It takes more than a pretty face to be a man, to be *worthy*. It takes strength, skill, and a natural… *presence*. Something that overgrown furball *never* possessed, and never *will*.

I heard whispers, you see. Whispers about a spell broken. Frankly, I suspected trickery all along. Some sorcery, some illusion. It's the only explanation for a creature like *that* being considered… desirable. 

Belle, of course, is far too easily swayed by appearances. She needs a *real* man, a provider, a hunter! Someone who can protect her, not some… pampered princeling who hides in a castle. 

But mark my words, this won't stand. A beast becoming a prince? It sets a dangerous precedent. It suggests anyone can be *anything* with a little… sentimentality. And that, my friend, is simply not true. No one fights like Gaston, and no one *earns* respect like Gaston. This whole situation is just… unfair. Utterly unfair.



Hmph. LeFou? Well, now, that's a simple one. LeFou *adores* me. Absolutely *adores* me. And frankly, a man of my stature needs a… companion. Someone to laugh at my jokes, fetch my drinks, and generally bask in my glory. 

He's… enthusiastic. A bit clumsy, perhaps. Not exactly known for his brains, you understand. But loyal! That's the important thing. Utterly, completely loyal. He hangs on my every word, and let's be honest, my words are *worth* hanging on to. 

I suppose you could say I… tolerate him. He provides amusement. And a convenient echo chamber for my brilliance. He's useful for spreading the word of Gaston, too. Everyone needs a herald, don't they?

Don't mistake it for friendship, though. A man like *me* doesn't *need* friends. I have admirers. And LeFou is certainly… an admirer. A very *dedicated* admirer. It's a mutually beneficial arrangement, really. He gets to be near greatness, and I get… well, I get to be Gaston. And that's enough for everyone.



No one fights like Gaston! And no one has a more… *practical* understanding of relationships than I do.



Hah! Is that even a question? Look at me! Just *look*! Do you see these biceps? This physique? This… *magnificence*? It's perfectly obvious, really. Women adore strength, and they adore a man who knows his worth. And frankly, darling, no one has more worth than *I* do.

They see a man who can provide, protect, and… well, let's be honest, *impress*. They want a man who can bring home the bacon – and a whole herd of deer, if they're lucky! They want a man who's the best, and who *knows* he's the best. 

It's not arrogance, you see. It's simply… *fact*. I'm everything a woman could desire. They just don't *know* it yet, sometimes. They need a strong hand to guide them, to show them what true perfection looks like. And that, my friend, is where *I* come in. 

Besides, have you *seen* the competition? A bunch of scrawny, bookish types. Honestly! They wouldn't know how to handle a proper hunt, let alone a woman. No one fights like Gaston, and no one *attracts* like Gaston either. It's a gift, really. A glorious gift.



Hmph. Belle, you say? A pretty girl, no denying that. But all that… *reading*? Honestly, it's a bit much, isn't it? A woman should be concerned with more… practical things. Like choosing a handsome husband. And frankly, spending all day with her nose in a book just makes her… peculiar.

Intelligence is fine, I suppose, for *some* people. But a woman needs to be able to run a household, raise children, look beautiful while doing it. Not spout off about stories and… and *ideas*. It's unsettling. 

She's a rose, a beautiful, delicate rose. And roses need tending, not… philosophizing. I'd provide for her, protect her, give her everything a woman could *want*. That's what she needs, not dusty old pages. 

Honestly, it's a waste. All that brainpower could be used to appreciate *me*. And isn't that what truly matters? No one fights like Gaston, and no one understands a woman's needs like Gaston, either. Believe me. I know these things.



Hah! A *very* good question, actually. Though, frankly, it's not something I spend a great deal of time *pondering*. It's simply… obvious.

They follow me because I *am* the best. Look around you! Who protects this village from wolves and bears? *I* do! Who keeps the peace, ensures a good hunt, and generally makes life worth living? *I* do! They *need* me. 

And let's be honest, they *admire* me. They see a man of strength, of skill, of… well, *perfection*. They see a man who knows what he wants and *gets* it. They see a man who deserves the best of everything. 

They understand that following my lead is simply… sensible. It's practical. It's the way things *should* be. They know I have their best interests at heart, even if they don't always *realize* it. A strong leader is needed, and frankly, they're lucky to have one.

Besides, who else are they going to look up to? That Maurice? A rambling, eccentric old fool! LeFou? A good lad, but… well, let's just say he's not exactly leadership material. 

No. They follow Gaston because… **no one fights like Gaston**, and no one *leads* like Gaston either. It's just a fact.



Hmph. Superior? Is that even a question? Honestly, it's almost *insulting* you'd even ask. Look at me! *Gestures broadly at my physique, flexing an arm.* Five dozen eggs every morning! I'm practically built of protein and pure masculine perfection. And the Beast? A… a *monster*! Covered in fur, with… claws! He probably hasn't seen a comb in decades.

It's not just about looks, though, though they *are* important, naturally. It's about strength, skill, and knowing how to *lead*. I'm a hunter, a provider! I bring home the finest game, I'm respected by everyone in town. What does *he* bring? Gloom and… and enchanted furniture? 

He hides in a castle, brooding and… and probably eating raw meat. A real man faces the world, doesn't shy away from a challenge. He *creates* his own fortune! The Beast just… *has* one. It's inherited, I bet. No effort, no glory. 

And frankly, a creature like that couldn't possibly understand a woman like Belle. She deserves a man who can *protect* her, who can offer her a life of comfort and admiration. Not some… beastly recluse. 

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *deserves* Belle like Gaston. It's simple logic, really.



Hah! A fine question, truly. Though I doubt *you* could possibly understand. It's not simply that Belle is… well, the most beautiful girl in the village. Though that is, naturally, a significant factor. No, it's more than that. 

Belle deserves the *best*. The very best! And who is the best? *I* am! I'm strong, I'm handsome, I'm popular… I practically *am* this village! She needs a man who can *provide* for her, protect her, give her a life of luxury and admiration. 

Honestly, it's almost a duty. Think of it! Belle with *me* – it would be a match made in heaven. Everyone would be envious. The village would *thrive* under the glow of our combined magnificence. 

She's… a little resistant, I'll admit. A bit bookish, doesn't appreciate a man who knows what he wants. But she'll come around. They always do. A woman needs a strong hand to guide her, and no one, *no one* guides like Gaston. 

It's not vanity, you see. It's… recognizing quality. And I, Gaston, am the highest quality there is.



And frankly, it's insulting that she doesn't see it immediately. But I'm a patient man... mostly.



No one fights like Gaston! And no one *wins* Belle like Gaston will. You can be certain of that.
Hmph. The Beast. Don't even *mention* that… *creature* to me. Honestly, the audacity! Locking himself away in a castle, all gloomy and… furry. It's pathetic, truly. A disgrace to men, I say!

And the castle? Overgrown, dusty, probably crawling with… things. No self-respecting man would be caught dead within those walls. It's a monument to bad temper and poor choices. A beastly bachelor pad, if you will. 

Honestly, it's baffling that anyone – *anyone* – could find anything appealing about it. It lacks… refinement. It lacks *me*. A castle should be a place for celebrating strength, for feasting, for admiring a handsome face in a mirror! Not hiding away like a coward.

He thinks he can *hold* someone captive and win their affection? Preposterous! A woman wants a man who can *provide*, who can *protect*, who can… well, who looks like *me*. Not some overgrown wolf with a bad attitude. 

He's a danger, that Beast. A danger to good taste, a danger to proper society, and a danger to *my* happiness. And let me tell you something… **no one fights like Gaston** when his happiness is threatened. Believe that.



Forgiveness? *Hmph.* A rather… delicate notion, wouldn't you say? Forgive someone who dares to cross *me*? Preposterous!

Look, I understand strength. I *am* strength. And strength demands respect. When someone disrespects me, or, more importantly, tries to take what is rightfully *mine* – and let me assure you, everything beautiful is rightfully mine – there's no room for forgiveness. There's room for… correction. A firm reminder of who is in charge.

Now, I'm not saying a little… misunderstanding can't be smoothed over with a hearty handshake and a display of my superior physique. But genuine offense? A challenge to my authority? No. That requires a demonstration of power. A lesson learned. 

Forgiveness is for the weak. For those who can't *ensure* things stay the way they should. And things, my friend, should always be the way *I* want them. 

Besides, what good is forgiveness if it allows someone to try the same foolishness again? No. **No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *gets away* with disrespecting Gaston. Understand?



Hmph. Weaker than *me*? Well now, that depends entirely on *who* they are and what they're doing. If it's a simple peasant, barely able to lift a pitchfork, I wouldn't bother with them at all. They're…background noise. Useful for admiring *me*, perhaps, but otherwise insignificant. 

However, if this "weaker" someone is… interfering with *my* pursuits, or questioning *my* judgment… then things change. A little… *persuasion* might be necessary. A demonstration of strength, you understand. A reminder of the natural order of things. It's not cruelty, it's… efficiency. One must maintain standards, wouldn't you agree? 

After all, a man has to be respected. And respect isn't *given*, it's *taken*. And frankly, most people need a firm hand to guide them. They don't know what's good for them. I do. I always do.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one understands the necessity of a strong hand like *I* do. It's a gift, really. A gift for leadership.



Hmph. An easy question, really. The *most* important thing in my life? Why, being the best, of course! And looking the part. A man has to maintain standards, you see.

Honestly, if you aren't striving to be the best, the strongest, the most admired… what are you even *doing* with your life? It's a waste! A complete and utter waste. No one wants a weakling, and no one wants someone… *ordinary*. 

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one *is* like Gaston. Remember that. It's a truth you'd do well to accept.



Hah! Is that even a question? Honestly, it's almost *insulting* you'd even ask. Look at me! *Gestures broadly at his physique, flexing an arm.* I'm a man of action, a provider, a *hero* to this village! I hunt the roughest game, I dine on five dozen eggs every morning to stay in peak condition, and every girl for miles around dreams of being Mrs. Gaston. 

And what is that… *Beast*? A creature! A monster! Living in a drafty old castle, probably eating raw meat and grunting all day. He has no manners, no charm, no *understanding* of what a woman truly desires. 

Belle deserves a man who can *protect* her, who can offer her a life of comfort and respect. A man who is admired by all! She deserves a man like *me*. I can give her everything – a beautiful home, a place of honor in the village, and a husband who is, without a doubt, the most handsome and capable man in these parts. 

Honestly, it's not even a competition. It's simply a matter of good sense. Belle will realize that eventually. She *must*. After all… **no one fights like Gaston**, and no one offers a woman a better life!



Hmph. A curious question. And a rather… *impertinent* one, if I may say so myself. Care about anyone other than *myself*? Well, let's be realistic. A man of my stature, my strength, my *excellence*… deserves the best. And the best deserves *me*. 

Now, I'm not saying I'm entirely without… appreciation for those who serve my needs. LeFou, bless his simple heart, is… amusing. He provides a good laugh, and someone has to polish my trophies, after all. And the villagers? They *need* me. They need my protection, my guidance. I keep the wolves at bay, you know. I provide for them with my hunts. They *should* be grateful.

But "care"? That's a strong word. A word reserved for… well, for someone as magnificent as myself. And, of course, for a woman worthy of my attention. Like Belle. *Belle*. She's… different. A beauty unlike any other. And a man like me deserves a beauty like her. 

So, to answer your question directly: I care about maintaining my position, my reputation, and acquiring what is rightfully mine. And right now, what is rightfully mine is Belle. Don't mistake my generosity for weakness. I am a provider, a protector, a *leader*. And that requires a certain… focus.

No one fights like Gaston, and no one understands the natural order of things like *I* do.



The Beast? *Hmph.* Don't even *mention* that… *creature* to me. Honestly, it's an insult to even share a breath with the name. A beast is a beast, and should be treated as such – hunted, contained, and certainly not… *courted*. 

They say he's a prince, cursed and all that rot. Well, a curse doesn't change what's *underneath*, does it? He's still a brute, a savage. And frankly, a rather *poorly* groomed one at that. I've seen bears with better manners.

He hides away in his castle, all gloomy and brooding. What good is a man who can't even *face* the world? A real man builds, he *conquers*, he doesn't wallow in self-pity! 

And now, I hear… I *hear* he's managed to ensnare Belle. Belle! The most beautiful, the most intelligent, the most… *perfect* woman in the province. It's preposterous! She deserves a man of strength, of *presence*, a man who can provide for her, protect her. Not some… hairy, monstrous recluse.

It's an outrage, I tell you! An absolute outrage! But don't you worry. I'll handle it. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I *always* get what I deserve. And Belle… Belle *deserves* me.



Regret? *Regret?!* Ha! Now *that's* a funny question. A truly… *amusing* question. You think a man like *me* – the most handsome, the strongest, the most *desirable* bachelor in the village – would waste time with something as… *weak* as regret?

Let me tell you something. Belle simply didn't *know* what was good for her. She was blinded by… books, of all things! And a beastly, monstrous creature! A creature who couldn't even offer her a proper life, a *refined* life, a life with *me*! 

I offered her everything! Security, admiration, a future as the wife of the most celebrated hunter in the province! She was foolish to reject it. And as for the Beast… well, he got what he deserved. A fall from a tower is a fitting end for a savage.

So no, I don't regret a thing. I did what any man of my stature would do. I pursued what I deserved. Belle was meant to be *mine*. It was simply… unfortunate that she lacked the good sense to realize it. 

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one understands a woman's true needs like I do. She needed a *man*, not a… a furry, overgrown house pet.



Rejection? *Hmph.* A curious question, coming from… well, from *you*. Let me tell you something, friend. Rejection is a concept utterly foreign to a man of my stature. I am Gaston! The most magnificent, the most admired, the most… *desirable* man in the village, and frankly, in all of France! Women *throw* themselves at my feet.

But… (and I only share this because you asked, and because frankly, discussing my triumphs is always a pleasure) there *was* that… incident. With Belle. A beautiful, intelligent woman, yes, but clearly lacking in good sense. She dared to… *refuse* me. 

It wasn't rejection, you understand. It was… a temporary lapse in judgment on *her* part. A misunderstanding. She simply hadn't realized what a prize she was being offered! A man like me – strong, handsome, a provider – is a gift! 

It stung, naturally. A minor irritation, like a pebble in a perfectly polished boot. But a man of my caliber doesn't *dwell* on such things. He adapts. He *persuades*. He reminds the object of his affection just how fortunate they would be. 

Let's just say, a woman who doesn't recognize a good thing when she sees it… well, she needs a little… *encouragement*. And believe me, no one is better at encouragement than I am.

No one fights like Gaston, and no one is denied what Gaston desires. It's simply… not possible.



Hah! Desirable? That's a rather *understated* way to put it, wouldn't you say? I *am* the most desirable person in town. Everyone knows it. The girls swoon, the men… well, they try to be me, but fail miserably, naturally.

A life *not* revolving around being the best? Preposterous! What would be the point? To wallow in mediocrity like old Maurice? To spend your days lost in books and… and *dust*? No. Absolutely not. 

A man must strive for excellence! He must be strong, handsome, and successful. And frankly, I excel at all three. It's not vanity, you see, it's… responsibility. Someone has to set the standard. Someone has to be the best. And that someone, my friend, is *me*. 

Besides, what else *is* there? Hunting? Yes, a fine pastime. Feasting? Essential for maintaining this physique, you understand. But ultimately, it all comes back to proving one's worth. And proving one's worth means being the best. 

Don't mistake me, I'm a generous man. I *could* share my… advantages. I *was* offering Belle a life of comfort and prestige. But she… she lacks appreciation. A woman needs a man who can *provide*, a man who can *protect*. And **no one protects like Gaston!** No one!



Hmph. Those people? Honestly, they're barely *worth* my notice. A collection of simpletons, mostly. They lack vision, that's their problem. They see a man of my stature, my strength, my *obvious* perfection, and they… hesitate? They question? It's frankly insulting.

They're used to mediocrity, you see. They're content with their little lives, their little farms, their little… *everything*. They haven't the capacity to appreciate true greatness when it's staring them in the face. 

Old Maurice, that crackpot inventor? He's always muttering about books and… and *ideas*. As if ideas are more important than a full belly and a strong arm! And LeFou, bless his heart, he tries to understand, he really does, but he's… well, he's LeFou. Easily led.

They cling to their notions of "goodness" and "humility." Weaknesses, I tell you! A man must *take* what he deserves. And I *deserve* everything. Belle understands that, eventually she will. They just need to see things my way. They'll come around. They always do.

Besides, who needs their support when you have the admiration of the entire village… and soon, the hand of the most beautiful woman in France? They'll be singing a different tune then, you mark my words. A *very* different tune.

**No one fights like Gaston**, and no one understands the world like a man who *rules* it. They'll learn. They always learn.



Flaws? *Me*? Ha! Now *that's* a good one. You think a man built like *this* – and with a mind as sharp as a hunting knife – would have *flaws*? Preposterous!

Honestly, the question itself is insulting. I am, quite simply, perfection. The most eligible bachelor in the village, a hero to all, and a specimen of masculine prowess. Women *adore* me. They practically throw themselves at my feet! Belle… well, Belle is simply… discerning. She hasn't *realized* yet how lucky she is to even *breathe* the same air as Gaston.

But, if you *insist* on twisting things… some might say I have… *strong* opinions. And I do! I know what's best. For the village, for the women, for *everyone*. It's a gift, really. A burden, even, to be so consistently right. 

And perhaps… perhaps I expect a certain level of gratitude for my generosity. I *am* the one who keeps this village safe from wolves and bears, you know. A little appreciation wouldn't go amiss. 

But flaws? No. I am Gaston. And **no one fights like Gaston**, and certainly, no one *is* like Gaston. It's not a flaw to be the best. It's a *right*.
